**Chiggers**

**What are chiggers?**

Chiggers, also known as harvest mites or red mites, are tiny insects that feed on the blood of animals and humans. They are usually found in outdoor areas with long grass and vegetation.

**Symptoms**

The symptoms of a chigger bite can include:

*   A red, itchy rash
*   Small blisters or bumps on the skin
*   The rash may appear on the parts of the body that were exposed to the sun

**Diagnosis**

Your health care provider can usually diagnose chiggers by examining the rash. You'll likely be asked about your outdoor activity. A special magnifying scope may be used to find the chiggers on the skin.

**Treatment**

The goal of treatment is to stop the itching. Antihistamines and corticosteroid creams or lotions may be helpful. Antibiotics are not necessary unless you develop a skin infection.

**Possible Complications**

A secondary infection may occur from scratching.

**When to Contact a Medical Professional**

Contact your provider if the rash itches very badly, or if your symptoms get worse or do not improve with treatment.

**Prevention**

Avoid outdoor areas that you know are contaminated with chiggers. Applying bug spray containing DEET to skin and clothing can help prevent chigger bites.

**Alternative Names**

Harvest mite; Red mite

**Images**

*   Chigger bite - close-up of blisters

title: Chikungunya virus: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Chikungunya Virus**

\n\n

**What is Chikungunya?**

Chikungunya is a virus passed to humans by the bite of infected mosquitoes. Symptoms include fever and severe joint pain. The name chikungunya (pronounced "chik-en-gun-ye") is an African word meaning "bent over in pain."

\n\n

**Where is Chikungunya Found?**

Before 2013, the virus was found only in Africa, Asia, Europe, and lands in the Indian and Pacific oceans. In late 2013, outbreaks occurred for the first time in the Americas in the Caribbean Islands.

In the Americas, local transmission of the disease has been found in 44 countries and territories. This means that mosquitoes in those areas have the virus and are spreading it to humans.

Since 2014, the disease has been found in travelers coming to the United States from affected areas in the Americas. Local transmission has occurred in Florida, Puerto Rico, the Dominican Republic, and Haiti.

\n\n

**How Does Chikungunya Spread?**

Mosquitoes spread the virus to humans. Mosquitoes pick up the virus when they feed on infected people. They spread the virus when they bite other people.

The mosquitoes that spread chikungunya are the same type that spread dengue fever, which has similar symptoms. These mosquitoes most often feed on humans during the day.

\n\n

**What Are the Symptoms of Chikungunya?**

Symptoms develop 3 to 7 days after being bitten by an infected mosquito. The disease is easily spread. Most people who become infected have symptoms.

The most common symptoms are fever and joint pain. Other symptoms include:

*   Headache
*   Joint swelling
*   Muscle pain
*   Nausea
*   Rash

Symptoms are similar to the flu and can be severe, but usually not deadly. Most people recover in a week. Some have joint pain for months or longer. The disease can lead to death in frail older adults.

\n\n

**How is Chikungunya Treated?**

There is no treatment for chikungunya. Like the flu virus, it has to run its course. You can take steps to help relieve symptoms:

*   Drink plenty of fluids to stay hydrated.
*   Get plenty of rest.
*   Take ibuprofen (Motrin, Advil), naproxen (Aleve, Naprosyn), or acetaminophen (Tylenol) to relieve pain and fever.

\n\n

**When Should I Contact a Medical Professional?**

Call your health care provider if you develop symptoms of chikungunya. Let your provider know if you have traveled recently in an area where the virus is spread. Your provider may do a blood test to check for the disease.

\n\n

**How Can I Prevent Chikungunya?**

There is no vaccine to protect against chikungunya. The best way to avoid getting the virus is to avoid getting bitten by mosquitoes. If you are in an area where there is local transmission of the virus, take these steps to protect yourself:

*   When it is not too hot, cover up with long sleeves, long pants, socks, and a hat.
*   Use clothing coated with permethrin.
*   Use insect repellent with DEET, picaridin, IR3535, oil of lemon eucalyptus, or para-menthane-diol. When using sunscreen, apply insect repellant after you apply sunscreen.
*   Sleep in a room with air conditioning or with windows with screens. Check screens for large holes.
*   Remove standing water from any outside containers such as buckets, flower pots, and birdbaths.
*   If sleeping outside, sleep under a mosquito net.

If you get chikungunya, try to avoid getting bitten by mosquitoes so you do not pass the virus to others.

**Chikungunya Virus**

\n\n**What is Chikungunya?**

Chikungunya is a viral disease spread by mosquitoes. It's characterized by severe joint pain and swelling, which can last for weeks or even months.

\n\n**Symptoms of Chikungunya**

* Severe joint pain and swelling
* Fever
* Headache
* Muscle pain
* Swelling in the joints

\n\n**Preventing Chikungunya**

To prevent Chikungunya, avoid areas with high mosquito activity, wear protective clothing, and use insect repellent.

\n\n**Treatment of Chikungunya**

There is no specific treatment for Chikungunya, but symptoms can be managed with pain relievers, rest, and hydration. In severe cases, hospitalization may be necessary.

title: Chikungunya: MedlinePlus
content:
**Chikungunya**

\n\n

**Summary**

Chikungunya is a virus spread by the same kinds of mosquitoes that spread dengue and Zika virus. Rarely, the virus can spread from the pregnant parent to their newborn around the time of birth. It may also spread through contact with infected blood. There have been outbreaks of chikungunya virus in Africa, Asia, Europe, the Indian and Pacific Oceans, the Caribbean, and Central and South America.

\n\n

**Symptoms**

Most people who have chikungunya will have symptoms, which can be severe. They usually start 3-7 days after being bitten by an infected mosquito. The most common symptoms are fever and joint pain. Other symptoms may include headache, muscle pain, joint swelling, and rash.

\n\n

**Treatment and Prevention**

Most people feel better within a week. In some cases, however, the joint pain may last for months. People at risk for more severe disease include newborns, older adults, and people with diseases such as high blood pressure, diabetes, or heart disease.

A blood test can show whether you have chikungunya virus. There are no medicines to treat it. Drinking lots of fluids, resting, and taking non-aspirin pain relievers might help you feel better.

In the U.S., there is a vaccine for adults who are at a higher risk of getting chikungunya. You can also help prevent getting or spreading chikungunya by avoiding mosquito bites:

*   Use a U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)-registered insect repellent when you go outdoors. Make sure to follow the instructions for using the repellant.
*   Wear clothes that cover your arms, legs, and feet.
*   Stay in places that either have air conditioning (with the windows closed) or that use window and door screens.

\n\n

**Centers for Disease Control and Prevention**

Most people feel better within a week. In some cases, however, the joint pain may last for months. People at risk for more severe disease include newborns, older adults, and people with diseases such as high blood pressure, diabetes, or heart disease.

A blood test can show whether you have chikungunya virus. There are no medicines to treat it. Drinking lots of fluids, resting, and taking non-aspirin pain relievers might help you feel better.

title: Child Abuse: MedlinePlus
content:
**Child Abuse**

**Basics**

* Child abuse is doing something or failing to do something that results in harm to a child or puts a child at risk of harm.
* Child abuse can be physical, sexual or emotional. Neglect, or not providing for a child's needs, is also a form of abuse.

**Summary**

* Most abused children suffer greater emotional than physical damage.
* An abused child may become depressed, withdraw, think of suicide or become violent.
* An older child may use drugs or alcohol, try to run away or abuse others.
* Child abuse is a serious problem. If you suspect a child is being abused or neglected, call the police or your local child welfare agency.

**Prevention and Risk Factors**

title: Child Behavior Disorders: MedlinePlus
content:
**Child Behavior Disorders**

Also called: Conduct disorders

**Basics**

All kids misbehave some times. And some may have temporary behavior problems due to stress. For example, the birth of a sibling, a divorce, or a death in the family may cause a child to act out. Behavior disorders are more serious. They involve a pattern of hostile, aggressive, or disruptive behaviors for more than 6 months. The behavior is also not appropriate for the child's age.

**Warning Signs**

Harming or threatening themselves, other people or pets
Damaging or destroying property
Lying or stealing
Not doing well in school, skipping school
Early smoking, drinking or drug use
Early sexual activity
Frequent tantrums and arguments
Consistent hostility toward authority figures

**What to Do**

If you see signs of a problem, ask for help. Poor choices can become habits. Kids who have behavior problems are at higher risk for school failure, mental health problems, and even suicide. Classes or family therapy may help parents learn to set and enforce limits. Talk therapy and behavior therapy for your child can also help.

**Start Here**

title: Child Dental Health: MedlinePlus
content:
**Child Dental Health**

Healthy teeth are important to your child's overall health. From the time your child is born, there are things you can do to promote healthy teeth and prevent cavities.

**For Babies:**

*   Clean teeth with a soft, clean cloth or baby's toothbrush.
*   Avoid putting the baby to bed with a bottle.
*   Check teeth regularly for spots or stains.

**For All Children:**

1.  Start using a pea-sized amount of fluoride toothpaste when they are two years old. You might start sooner, if a dentist or doctor suggests it.
2.  Provide healthy foods and limit sweet snacks and drinks
3.  Schedule regular dental check-ups

Forming good habits at a young age can help your child have healthy teeth for life.

**Resources:**

*   NIH: National Institute of Dental and Craniofacial Research

title: Child Development: MedlinePlus
content:
**Child Development**

As children grow older, they develop in several different ways. Child development includes physical, intellectual, social, and emotional changes.

* **Physical Changes**: Children grow and mature at very different rates. It's hard to say what "normal" is. There can be big differences in height, weight, and build among healthy children. Diet, exercise, and genes are all factors.
* **Intellectual Changes**: Some children begin puberty or are close to it before they are teenagers.

**Social and Emotional Changes**

Children start to become more independent from their parents. They may rebel. They also look outward - to their friends, who are usually of the same sex. Peer approval becomes very important. Your child may try new behaviors to be part of "the group." This can also be the time that parents or teachers recognize learning disabilities or behavioral problems in children.

**Recognizing Learning Disabilities and Behavioral Problems**

These problems can get worse as time goes on, so it is important to get help early.

**Resources**

* **Centers for Disease Control and Prevention**: Child Development
* **Nemours Foundation**: Growth and Development
* **National Library of Medicine**: Developmental and Behavioral Screening Tests

**Treatments and Therapies**

* **Medications to Treat Bed-Wetting**: National Kidney Foundation
* **Physical Therapy**: Nemours Foundation
* **Speech-Language Therapy**: Nemours Foundation

---

**Child Development**

As your child grows and develops, they will start to try new behaviors to fit in with "the group." This can also be the time that parents or teachers recognize learning disabilities or behavioral problems in children. These problems can get worse as time goes on, so it is important to get help early.

**Start Here**

*   **Child Development (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention)**: Learn about the different stages of child development and how to support your child's growth.
*   **Growth and Development (Nemours Foundation)**: Find information on child development, including physical, emotional, and social growth.

---

**Child Development**

**Temper Tantrums**

Children's development is a complex process that involves physical, emotional, and cognitive growth. One of the most challenging aspects of child development is dealing with temper tantrums. These outbursts are a normal part of childhood, usually occurring between 1 to 3 years of age.

**Related Health Topics**

*   **Child Behavior Disorders**: Conditions that affect a child's behavior, such as attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) or oppositional defiant disorder.
*   **Developmental Disabilities**: Conditions that affect a child's development, such as Down syndrome or cerebral palsy.
*   **Growth Disorders**: Conditions that affect a child's growth and development, such as Turner syndrome or Klinefelter syndrome.
*   **Infant and Newborn Development**: The physical and emotional growth of infants and newborns.
*   **Puberty**: The process of physical and emotional change during adolescence.
*   **Teen Development**: The physical and emotional growth of teenagers.

**National Institutes of Health**

The primary NIH organization for research on child development is the Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development. This institute conducts research on various aspects of child development, including physical and emotional growth, behavior, and health.

title: Child Mental Health: MedlinePlus
content:
**Child Mental Health**

It's essential to recognize and treat mental illnesses in children early on. Once mental illness develops, it becomes a regular part of your child's behavior, making it more challenging to treat.

**Warning Signs**

Identifying warning signs is crucial. Everyday stresses can cause temporary changes in behavior, but be aware of the following:

*   Problems in multiple settings (school, home, peers)
*   Changes in appetite or sleep
*   Social withdrawal or fear of things they weren't afraid of before
*   Returning to behaviors common in younger children, such as bedwetting
*   Signs of being upset, like sadness or tearfulness
*   Self-destructive behavior, like head-banging or frequent injuries
*   Repeated thoughts of death

**Diagnosis and Treatment**

To diagnose mental health issues, doctors or specialists consider your child's signs, symptoms, medical history, and family history. Treatments may include medications and talk therapy.

**Resources**

For more information:

*   **Centers for Disease Control and Prevention**: About Children's Mental Health
*   **National Institute of Mental Health**: Child and Adolescent Mental Health
*   **American Academy of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry**: Comprehensive Psychiatric Evaluation

---

**Child Mental Health**

Recognizing and treating mental illnesses in children early on is crucial, as once mental illness develops, it becomes a regular part of your child's behavior, making it more difficult to treat.

**Warning Signs**

Warning signs that it might be a more serious problem include:

* Everyday stresses causing changes in your child's behavior
* Getting a new brother or sister or going to a new school may cause a child to temporarily act out

**Diagnosis and Tests**

To diagnose mental health problems, the doctor or mental health specialist looks at your child's signs and symptoms, medical history, and family history. Treatments include medicines and talk therapy.

* Comprehensive Psychiatric Evaluation (American Academy of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry)
* Mental Health Screening  (National Library of Medicine)
* Mental Illness in Children: Know the Signs (Mayo Foundation for Medical Education and Research)

**Learn More**

Depression in children and teens can have serious consequences if left untreated. Learn more about recognizing the signs and seeking help.

* Depression in Children and Teens (American Academy of Family Physicians)

**Treatments and Therapies**

Mental health treatments for children include medicines, talk therapy, and residential treatment programs. It's essential to find the right treatment plan for your child.

* Mental Health Medications  (National Institute of Mental Health)
* Psychotherapies  (National Institute of Mental Health)
* Residential Treatment Programs (American Academy of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry)

**Related Issues**

Children's mental health is closely linked to their overall well-being. Learn more about related issues such as:

* Adverse Childhood Experiences (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention)
* Building Resilience in Children (American Academy of Pediatrics)
* Helping Children and Adolescents Cope With Traumatic Events  (National Institute of Mental Health)

**Specifics**

Anxiety disorders, bipolar disorder, childhood depression, and disruptive mood dysregulation disorder are all serious mental health conditions that require prompt attention.

* Anxiety Disorders (Nemours Foundation)
* Bipolar Disorder in Children and Teens  (National Institute of Mental Health)

title: Child Nutrition: MedlinePlus
content:
**Child Nutrition**

A healthy diet helps children grow and learn. It also helps prevent obesity and weight-related diseases, such as diabetes.

**To Give Your Child a Nutritious Diet:**

*   Make half of what is on your child's plate fruits and vegetables
*   Choose healthy sources of protein, such as lean meat, nuts, and eggs
*   Serve whole-grain breads and cereals because they are high in fiber. Reduce refined grains.
*   Broil, grill, or steam foods instead of frying them
*   Limit fast food and junk food
*   Offer water or milk instead of sugary fruit drinks and sodas

**Learn About Your Children's Nutrient Requirements:**

Some of them, such as the requirements for iron and calcium, change as your child ages.

**Resources:**

*   Healthy Eating (Nemours Foundation)

**Child Safety**

Are you concerned about keeping your child safe? Look no further than MedlinePlus, a trusted resource for health information. Here, we'll explore the importance of child safety and provide you with valuable resources to ensure your little one stays protected.

**Safety Tips**

Before we dive into the resources, let's cover some essential safety tips:

* Always buckle up: Make sure your child is securely fastened into their car seat or booster seat.
* Supervise, supervise, supervise: Keep a close eye on your child at all times, especially around water, stairs, and other hazards.
* Educate yourself: Stay informed about the latest child safety guidelines and recommendations.

**Resources**

Now that you're equipped with some basic safety tips, it's time to explore the resources below:

* **Child Safety Checklist**: A bilingual PDF guide to help you identify potential hazards in your home and take steps to prevent accidents.
* **Safety with Car Seats and Booster Seats**: A bilingual PDF resource providing tips on how to properly install and use car seats and booster seats.
* **Children's Safety Resources**: A collection of HTML resources offering advice on various child safety topics, including water safety, stranger danger, and more.

**AMBER Alerts**

In the event of a child abduction or emergency, it's crucial to act quickly. That's where AMBER Alerts come in – a system designed to disseminate critical information to the public via cell phones, radio, and other media outlets. Learn more about this vital service:

* **AMBER Alerts**: HTML resources available in English, Spanish, Tagalog, and Vietnamese.

**Additional Resources**

For further guidance on child safety, consider exploring these additional resources:

* **Children's Safety Resources**: A bilingual HTML collection offering advice on various child safety topics.
* **Child Safety Checklist**: A bilingual PDF guide to help you identify potential hazards in your home and take steps to prevent accidents.

By following these tips and utilizing the resources provided, you'll be well on your way to creating a safer environment for your child. Remember, safety is everyone's responsibility – let's work together to keep our little ones protected!

title: Child Safety: MedlinePlus

* Install the right child safety seat in your car
* Teach children how to cross the street safely
* Make sure they wear the right gear and equipment for sports

* Store medicines, cleaners and other dangerous substances in locked cabinets

title: Child Sexual Abuse: MedlinePlus
content:
**Child Sexual Abuse**

**Basics**

Sexual abuse is one form of child abuse, including a wide range of actions between a child and an adult or older child. It often involves body contact, but not always. Exposing one's genitals to children or pressuring them for sex is sexual abuse. Using a child for pornography is also sexual abuse.

**Summary**

Most sexual abusers know the child they abuse. They may be family friends, neighbors, or babysitters. About one-third of abusers are related to the child. Most abusers are men. If you think a child may have been abused, it's essential to report it.

**Start Here**
